Definition / general

* Common inflammatory reaction of palatal minor salivary gland orifices that results from smoking tobacco, electronic cigarettes, marijuana or frequent consumption of hot beverages
  + This inflammatory reaction is mounted in response to both heat and chemicals released from burning substances

Essential features

* Clinically appears as papules with central red umbilications; the papules correspond to obstructed palatal minor salivary glands and the red umbilications correspond to their inflamed duct orifices ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol 1965;20:306](14342920))
  + Common finding in patients who smoke or frequently drink hot beverages* Keratosis and acanthosis of palatal epithelium with underlying patchy, chronic inflammation involving minor salivary glands and squamous metaplasia of salivary duct epithelium* Inflammatory changes of minor salivary gland ductal orifices resolve within 2 - 4 weeks of cessation of smoking or consumption of hot drinks ([Br J Cancer 1971;25:403](5144514))

Terminology

* Nicotine stomatitis was first documented in 1926 in a comprehensive study by Fordyce and MacKee, who both named the lesion mucous adenoma of the roof of the mouth ([Arch Dermatol 1926;13:601](https://doi.org/10.1001/archderm.1926.02370170003001))* In 1936, McCarthy referred to the lesions as smoker’s patches and vehemently stated that the use of tobacco was the most important etiologic factor of these lesions ([Arch Derm Syphilol 1936;34:612](http://doi.org/10.1001/archderm.1936.01470160059007))* Stomatitis nicotina was a term introduced by Thoma in 1937 ([Arch Dermatol 1961;83:945](13700854))
      + Thoma postulated the condition was a periodic, desquamating leukoplakia arising from small cyst formation within the salivary tissue of the palate with inflamed duct orifices ([Arch Dermatol 1961;83:945](13700854))* Smoker’s keratosis was a term coined in the dermatologic literature by Cooke in 1956 ([Br J Dermatol 1956;68:151](13315882))* The designation of nicotine stomatitis was first introduced in the literature by Saunders in 1958, who stated this nomenclature was used by dental pathologists and oral surgeons; additionally, Saunders mentioned that papular leukoplakia was a frequently used synonym for this entity ([Ann Otol Rhinol Laryngol 1958;67:618](13583891))

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [K13.24](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/K00-K95/K00-K14/K13-/K13.24) - leukokeratosis nicotina palati* ICD-11: [DA01.0Y](https://icd.who.int/browse/2024-01/mms/en#308785511%2Fother) - other specified disturbances of oral epithelium

Epidemiology

* Predominantly occurs in male tobacco smokers in the third through fifth decades of life ([Br J Cancer 1971;25:403](5144514))

Sites

* Involves the minor salivary glands of the hard palate posterior to the rugae and the adjoining soft palate

Pathophysiology

* Nicotine stomatitis is an inflammatory reaction to heat and chemical irritants from tobacco products and hot beverages
  + These irritants induce inflammation of the palatal mucosa and minor salivary gland ductal orifices, squamous metaplasia of salivary ducts and keratosis as well as acanthosis of the palatal mucosa ([Tob Induc Dis 2024;22:10.18332/tid/189600](38933523))

Etiology

* Smoking tobacco products, including conventional and reverse smoking of cigarettes and cigars ([Br J Cancer 1971;25:403](5144514))
  + High temperatures of hot beverages have been observed to have a concerted effect ([Tob Induc Dis 2024;22:10.18332/tid/189600](38933523))
    - In one case report, a woman who did not smoke but frequently drank hot beverages had palatal lesions that resembled nicotinic stomatitis, which further suggests heat as an etiologic factor ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol 1990;70:597](2234881))* This inflammatory change is also noted in those who use electronic cigarettes and smoke marijuana ([Acta Odontol Scand 2018;76:226](29161938), [Cureus 2023;15:e48868](38106782))

Clinical features

* Lesions are asymptomatic papules with central red umbilications of the hard palate posterior to the palatal rugae and may extend onto the soft palate* Dried mud appearance of the palatal mucosa may also be seen

Diagnosis

* Papules with central red umbilications of the hard and soft palate may be detected as an incidental finding

Prognostic factors

* Prognosis is excellent; lesions resolve within 2 - 4 weeks of smoking cessation or cessation of routine hot beverage consumption ([Br J Cancer 1971;25:403](5144514))

Case reports

* 27 year old man with a history of smoking presented with a chief complaint of reddish spots on the back of his throat ([Cureus 2023;15:e48868](38106782))* 28 year old man presented with chief complaint of white spots on his palate ([J Dentomaxillofac Sci 2018;3:58](https://jdmfs.org/index.php/jdmfs/article/view/708))* 50 year old man with a history of smoking tobacco in the form of beedi (form of tobacco smoking without filter, a common practice in parts of Asia) ([J Dent Oral Disord 2017;3:1055](https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Vijayendranath-Nayak/publication/341495092_SMOKERS_HYPERPLASIA/links/5ec43e80299bf1c09acbdd93/SMOKERS-HYPERPLASIA.pdf))

Treatment

* No treatment is required; lesions resolve within 2 - 4 weeks of smoking cessation or cessation of routine hot beverage consumption ([Br J Cancer 1971;25:403](5144514))

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Keratosis and acanthosis of surface epithelium ([Br J Cancer 1971;25:403](5144514))* Mild, patchy, chronic inflammation of the connective tissue stroma and minor seromucous glands
    + Inflammatory excretion may be seen within the lumina of striated salivary ducts ([Br J Cancer 1971;25:403](5144514))* Squamous metaplasia of ductal epithelium near the orifice may be seen in instances of papular elevation ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol 1965;20:306](14342920))

Positive stains

* Immunohistochemistry is often unneeded for diagnosis
  + [CAM 5.2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainscam52.html) and [SOX10](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsSOX10.html) may be used to highlight metaplastic salivary ducts ([Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:593](31541432), [Mod Pathol 2013;26:1041](23558573))

Sample pathology report

* Posterior hard palatal mucosa, left incisional biopsy:
  + Hyperkeratosis, squamous ductal metaplasia and chronic sialadenitis (see comment)+ Comment: The histologic findings are consistent with nicotine stomatitis.

Differential diagnosis

* [Subacute necrotizing sialadenitis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitynecrotizingsialo.html):
  + Extensive acinar necrosis+ Foci of mixed inflammation, including neutrophils, eosinophils and mononuclear inflammatory cells+ No ductal squamous metaplasia ([Head Neck Pathol 2016;10:425](27008639))* [Necrotizing sialometaplasia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/salivaryglandsnecrotizingsialo.html):
    + Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia of the surface epithelium may be seen+ Ulceration of the surface epithelium with underlying acute inflammation is often observed+ Lobular architecture of minor salivary glands is usually preserved and squamous ductal metaplasia is often noted in mature lesions* [Dysplasia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitydysplasia.html):
      + Basal hyperplasia and bulbous, tear dropped shaped rete ridges+ Nuclear and cellular pleomorphism+ Increased mitotic activity, increased N:C ratio, dyskeratosis and glassy appearing cytoplasm+ Dysplastic changes of overlying surface epithelium may track down nearby salivary ducts* [Erythematous candidiasis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityinfectionsgeneral.html):
        + Spongiosis and mild acanthosis of surface epithelium+ Acute and chronic inflammation with transmigratory neutrophils forming microabscesses in the stratum granulosum+ Pseudohyphae are seen oriented perpendicular to the surface epithelium and are embedded in the stratum corneum* [Herpetic stomatitis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityinfectionsgeneral.html):
          + Intraepidermal blisters with discohesive epithelium that burst, ulcerate and often coalesce
            - Recurrent episodes are typically unilateral along affected dermatome+ Involved keratinocytes exhibit cytopathic effect, including margination of chromatin, nuclear inclusions and multinucleation
              - Nuclear inclusions are small, eosinophilic deposits with clear halation
